reviewText:
Dodge is a losing-is-fun minimalistic game. I spent about 1 hr to finish the whole game and I will recommend this to my friends if they are not ragequitters. In fact I usually like such games to while away hours.

From the name you can hazard a guess that it's kinda a game sharpening your reflexes, making you cry or ragequit, or whatever, only after giving it a try you will indulge in it. Basically it isn't too hard for me, I'd believe that comparing with Super Meatboy it's pretty much easier. I'd also like to emphasize my pithy advice that please do not equate the game's good or bad with your capacity...

Moving square on a grid is challenging when there are lots of enemy dots coming over, with the black and white style you will think it's confusing but I'm fine with it anyway.

Meanwhile Dodge can be expanded to 100 levels with randomized dot tracks, and randomized colors even in different levels, again I'm fine with the current game, it's extraodinaryly designed and I'm already fascinated by it.

reviewText: You are a square. You have tiles and you must move from tile to tile to avoid tiny squares of death from hitting you. At the end of each stage you must collect a hollow square. Not much depth and there's really not a lot to be had here.\nGets old really fast and the one song included will get annoying.\nThere are better games out there, for a dollar more you could get Super Hexagon" or "Boson X"
date: both of which are better games than this.\nWould only reccommend to people who like arcadey timewasters like the games mentioned before
recommended: other than that there's not too much to be had.\n"

reviewText: Review originally posted at Apoch's Metal Review[www.apochs.net].\n\nDespite all the advancements in gaming today, the indie development world still manages to turn out some fairly simple games for those looking for a breather from the big name franchises of today. This is the case with Dodge, an Action/Puzzle style title from independent publisher and developer named Yokcos. According to the official blog, it's a game that was crafted in forty eight hours" through Game Maker
date: as well as SFXR to create the audio. The venture has received a fair deal of praise from users and the media alike for being an example of "minimalism" in a complicated world
recommended: but does Dodge have anything to offer gamers today
hoursPlayed: or is it actually something far more pointless?\n\nDodge is
voteText: by all accounts
helpfulPercent: a truly minimalistic experience. The core concept is simple: Avoid the incoming obstacles. You are presented a limited grid and are allowed to move frequently on it
votesHelpful: as well as move off the edge to appear on the opposite side. There's also two different ways to play. The main allure is "Infinity"
votesTotal: which is essentially a survival mode that pits you on a three-by-three field against various obstacles such as the bullets and random lines that can block your path to safety. There's also various short levels you can tackle
votesFunny: forcing you to stay alive until a rich block outline appears
commentsCount: which you need to let make contact with you in order to finish the stage. There is a total of thirty of those short stages.\n\nPretty much everything about this game screams the early days of Intellivision and Atari 2600 titles
column16: just with a crisp presentation and a limited .MIDI soundtrack that sounds like a Punk song turned eight-bit against simple effects. The other dramatic alteration is more of a cosmetic one that lies within the Options menu
column17: which manipulates the colors on screen. You have your traditional black and white/white and black appearance
column20: both of which are about the same thing
column22: complete with a justified warning due to the intense strobe light effect it creates.\n\nBut
column25: it all depends. Are you looking for something relatively simple but with a growing difficulty curve? If so
column26: then Dodge is something you'll get a kick out of. The main killing point is that this release costs two dollars US at this point. While it does offer a good amount of replay value thanks to "Infinity" mode
column27: the game itself does get incredibly repetitive pretty quick. Plus
column28: knowing it was developed in forty-eight hours does make you feel as though you're being a bit overcharged. If you're tired of long
column29: convoluted stories with complex controls and just want something simple you can pick up and play
column31: though worth waiting for a sale on if you can't justify paying the full price given the aforementioned blog post description dismissing an extensive development regime.\n\nOverall Score: 6.5/10"

reviewText: Sometimes less is more, and this game proves that is true.   You can have as much fun with this game which costs you $2 as you would with a $50 AAA title.    With the ability to play for infinity and see how long you can last, there is no end to the game.    I find the game fun and enjoyable.    The game is worth playing anytime you have a few minutes to spare or even an hour or more to spare if you want to play to infinity.

reviewText:
Extremely simple, but quite challenging, Dodge has very basic graphics and a very basic premise: move your geometric marker to avoid other incoming markers, dots, lines, etc.

Graphics are poor, sound is poor, and gameplay is very repetetive. It is an interesting puzzle/twitch game, but without anything to keep me coming back, I only made it just past level 20. It's not fun enough to play any more than that.

Not recommended unless you can pick it up for less than the sale value of the trading cards.

reviewText:
It may seem good to start off with, but it gets repetitive quite quickly...

The game is a simple black and white game (a bit similar to pong) with its rock playing in the background - which I find a bit cheesy and distracting. The game lacks colour (since its mostly black and white) and there are no good features to it apart from its a simple black and white game.

All in all, I'm pretty disappointed with my purchase.
